title: Sociolinguistic Ethnography in a Changing Society
abstractText:
‘Ethnography, Language & Communication’ is a training programme funded under the Researcher Development Initiative, and it aims to help doctoral and post-doctoral researchers do justice to textual data by providing them with the tools of linguistic ethnography (LE). LE takes the view:

  • that meaning is shaped within specific social relations, interactional histories and institutional regimes, produced and construed by agents with expectations and repertoires that have to be grasped ethnographically; and
  • that meaning is more than just the content of words, and biography, identifications, stance and nuance are extensively signalled in the sociolinguistic fine-grain.

LE methods are very well established in US Linguistic Anthropology, but outside socio- and applied linguistics, LE is little known in Britain. This three year programme consists of 20 trainings days, and involves:

  • two 5-day courses on ‘Frameworks & Procedures’
  • four 1-day follow-up support sessions
  • four 1-day thematic application workshops (on health, education, new media, asylum and immigration)
  • two Master classes

We will also develop training materials, hold a day conference on Teaching LE, and link into the UK Linguistic Ethnography Forum, the ESRC Identity & Social Action Programme, and the ESRC/NRCM RLM node.
impactText: Well over 500 doctoral and post-doctoral researchers from a range of backgrounds and interests (psychology, anthropology, linguistics, health, education, and management, among others) have received intensive 5 day training in linguistic ethnography. findingsText: This was an Advanced Methods Training Programme funded under the ESRC Research Development Initiative, and as such, it did not produce findings. However, it did lead to the setting up of an annual conference ('Explorations in Linguistic Ethnography') and formed part of King's College London's successful bid to become an ESRC Doctoral Training Centre (www.kcl.ac.uk/kissdtc). The summer school that we established with ESRC funding is still continuing as an annual event (support by the ESRC through the King's DTC).
